subject: Re: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception ?

messageBody:
I agree with the point that listing all the possible exceptions
greatly increases code maintenance. The goal was to know what
exception was thrown if the specific exception being tested is not
thrown (without having to go to a stack trace). This goal can be
accomplished by catching Exception with a fail in the catch block and
including the name of the exception in the fail message.

The test method below has three possible out comes:

1. The specific exception is thrown and the test succeeds.
2. The test fails without throwing an exception.
3. The test fails by throwing an exception different from the
specific exception being tested (and the name of the unexpected
exception is in the fail message).

// Test SpecificException is thrown under conditions...
public void test_00_methodName() {

try {
instanceClass.methodName(argument);
fail("SpecificException should be thrown.
No exception was thrown.");

} catch (SpecificException se) {

assert(true);

} catch (Exception e){

fail("SpecificException should be thrown.
The follwoing exception was thrown:" +
e.toString);
}
}
